questions.text: Drug of choice for type III hyperlipoproteinemia is
questions.solution:
Fibrates are the drug of choice for patients with type III hyperlipoproteinemia and those with severe hypertriglyceredemia (TG >1000 mg/dl)who are at risk for pancreatitis. 

Type III hyperlipoproteinemia patients are most sensitive responders to fibrate therapy. 

  • Elevated triglyceride and cholesterol levels are dramatically lowered.
  • Tuberoeruptive and palamr xanthomas may regress completely.
  • Angina and intermittent claudication also improve.

questions.text: Penicillin G is the drug of choice for all of the following conditions except_________.
questions.solution:
Penicillin G is not the drug of choice for Lyme disease. Penicillin G is an alternative to third-generation cephalosporins in the treatment of severe Lyme disease. 

Lyme disease is transmitted by the bite of Ixodid ticks (hard ticks).

The disease occurs in 3 stages:

Primary stage - characterized by the characteristic bull’s eye rash. The rash starts as a small macule at the site of the tick bite and gradually expands with central clearing.
Secondary stage - characterized by secondary annular skin rashes, migratory arthritis, fever, and generalized lymphadenopathy. This stage can be associated with neurological abnormalities like aseptic meningitis and cranial nerve palsies. Patients may also develop myocarditis with associated AV block.
Tertiary stage - characterized by chronic arthritis, cranial nerve palsies, ataxia, and dermatitis. 
Doxycycline is the drug of choice in the initial stages of Lyme disease when there is no CNS involvement. If there is CNS involvement, i.v. ceftriaxone is used for treatment.

Options A and D: Penicillin G is the drug of choice for all forms of actinomycosis and rat-bite fever. 

Option B: Ampicillin or penicillin G is the drug of choice for Listeria infections.

questions.text: The drug of choice in Zollinger Ellison syndrome is ______
questions.solution:
Proton-pump inhibitors are the drug of choice in Zollinger–Ellison syndrome. 

Zollinger Ellison Syndrome (ZES)/Gastrinoma is a neuroendocrinal tumor characterized by hypersecretion of gastrin resulting in gastrointestinal tract ulcers. It occurs more commonly in a sporadic pattern but can be associated with MEN-1 (multiple endocrine neoplasia-1) syndromes in the familial pattern. There is secretion of large amounts of gastrin, which inturn increases gastric acid leading to severe gastroduodenal ulceration and other effects of hyperchlorhydria.

Treatment of ZES: High-dose Proton Pump Inhibitor followed by surgery.

Surgeries that can be done are:

Distal Pancreatectomy – if a lesion in the body or tail of the pancreas
Enucleation – if a lesion in the head of the pancreas
Full-thickness excision – if lesion in duodenum
MEN associated – surgery done only if size>2.5cm  

Related Pearl: Clinical features of gastrinoma (Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome)

Most common symptom: Abdominal pain.

Gastrin hypersecretion stimulates gastric acid secretion, leading to peptic ulcers that occur at atypical sites like the duodenum and jejunum and are refractory and multiple.

Diarrhea is due to

  • Acid-induced injury to the small intestine mucosa
  • Inability of the intestinal tract to absorb large volumes of fluids secreted by the stomach
  • Inactivation of pancreatic lipase by low pH
  • Precipitation of bile salts.

The unique characteristic of acid-induced diarrhea is that it is controlled by nasogastric aspiration of gastric secretions.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with hepatitis and personality changes. A picture of her eye has been provided below. Which of the following is the drug of choice for pregnant women and maintenance therapy for this condition?
questions.solution:
The image provided above represents the Kayser-Fleischer ring which is seen in Wilson's disease. The drug of choice for maintenance therapy in this condition is Zinc.

Wilsons disease is an autosomal-recessive disease caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene, which encodes a membrane-bound, copper-transporting ATPase.

Kayser-Fleischer ring (KF) ring is a golden-brown ring formed due to the deposition of copper in Descemet’s membrane of the cornea. It is characteristically observed in Wilson's disease but is not pathognomic. It does not interfere with vision. It is present in almost all patients of Wilson's disease with neurological/psychiatric symptoms. However, the absence of KF rings does not exclude the diagnosis of Wilson's disease

Clinical symptoms:

  • Hepatitis and cirrhosis
  • Neurological: Dystonia, rigidity, tremor or choreiform movements, abnormal gait due to basal ganglia (e.g., caudate, putamen) involvement.
  • Behavioural disturbancesOccular characteristics:
    • Deposition of copper in the posterior capsule of the lens resulting in sunflower cataract
    • KF ring 

Diagnosis:

    • Sternlieb's criteria: Presence of KF rings
    • Decreased serum ceruloplasmin (copper-containing enzyme/ferroxidase) levels
    • Measured hepatic copper levels in liver biopsy
    • Increased 24-hour urine copper excretion

The gold standard for diagnosis: Liver biopsy with quantitative copper assays

The initial treatment in symptomatic patients is the administration of copper-chelating agents, which leads to the rapid excretion of excess deposited copper.

  • D-penicillamine: It increases urinary excretion of copper and prevents copper overload. Pyridoxine (vitamin B6 ) is administered along with it to counter pyridoxine deficiency that occurs due to penicillamine.
  • Triethylenetetramine dihydrochloride: This chelating agent is given in patients intolerant to D-penicillamine and those with severe neurologic manifestations (D-penicillamine worsens neurological status).
  • Zinc acetate: This is used due to its unique ability to impair the gastrointestinal absorption of copper. Zinc is beneficial in pregnancy (lower teratogenic effects) and as a maintenance therapy.
  • Liver transplantation: This is considered in advanced stages of irreversible hepatic damage or poor compliance to medical therapy.

questions.text: A known hypertensive patient is brought to the ER with palpitations and breathlessness. On examination, his BP was 220/140 with signs of encephalopathy. Which of the following is used as a 1st line drug to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario points towards a diagnosis of hypertensive encephalopathy. The drug of choice in this scenario is IV nicardipine.

Hypertensive emergencies are situations in which grade 3 hypertension (BP>180/110 mmHg) is associated with acute hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD).

Treatment of hypertensive emergency depends on the type of end-organ damage present (as shown in the table below). It is treated with rapidly acting intravenous antihypertensive agents.

In hypertensive encephalopathy, the initial goal of therapy is to immediately reduce mean arterial blood (MAP) pressure by no more than 25%. Rapid reduction of blood pressure may lead to reduced cerebral blood flow and result in cerebral infarction.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best way of preventing the development of deep vein thrombosis in the postoperative period?
questions.solution:
Heparin especially low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is the choice for prophylaxis of DVT.

LMWH inhibits factor Xa and not IIa activity, with the ratio of anti-factor Xa to anti-factor IIa activity ranging from 1: 1 to 4: 1

Advantages:

  • LMWH has a longer plasma half-life and significantly higher bioavailability.
  • The consistent bioavail­ability and clearance of LMWH do not require monitoring of factor Xa levels, which facilitates use by the patient.
  • No laboratory monitoring is necessary because the partial thrombo­plastin time (PTT) is unaffected.
  • Dosing is merely based on the patient’s weight.
  • There is a more predictable anticoagulant response than with unfractionated heparin.

Note: 

The given mcq is controversial because, the choice of prophylaxis depends on the type of surgery, trauma and duration of post operative immobilastion.

  • Major trauma, abdominal and orthopedic surgeries warrants a longer duration of post operative immobilsation. Pharmacological method is efficacious in these situations.

  • Patients who are expected to be up and walking within 24 to 48 hours after a minor trauma, operations are at low risk for development of venous thrombosis. Mechanical method is advised in these situations. The simplest method is for the patient to walk. Activation of the calf pump mechanism is an effective means of prophylaxis.

Overall, heparin reduce the risk for symptomatic and asymptomatic venous thrombombolic episode by 60 to 70% should be considered as a choice in unspecified situation ( eg: above MCQ).

questions.text: A child presents with continuing seizures for the past 30 minutes. The relatives say that there had been no seizure-free intervals in the past 30 minutes. After stabilizing the vitals of the patient, the first drug the patient should be started on is:
questions.solution:
This scenario described above is of status epilepticus. The first line drug used is Diazepam/Lorazepam.

Status epilepticus refers to continuous or repetitive, discrete seizures with impaired consciousness which lasts for more than 5 minutes.

The duration of seizure activity to meet the definition of status epilepticus has traditionally been specified as 15–30 min. However, a more practical definition is to consider status epilepticus as a situation in which the duration of seizures prompts the acute use of anticonvulsant therapy, i.e., more than 5 minutes.

questions.text: A patient comes to the OPD with a history significant of a mood disorder. Her moods can be charted as shown in the image. What will be the best drug for her?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from rapid cycling bipolar disorder. Sodium valproate is the drug of choice for this disorder.

Diagnosis of rapid cycling bipolar disorder:

  • 4 or more mood disturbances in a year
  • Episodes either have a partial or full remission for atleast 2 months or switch to the opposite polarity

A recent trial found that increased levels of parathyroid hormone in patients with bipolar disorder were associated with worse clinical outcomes. Researchers suggest vitamin D supplementation as a possible add on treatment.

Related Pearl: Patterns of Mood Disorders

questions.text: A 9-year-old child does not follow instructions, is disruptive, interferes when two people are talking, and cannot wait for his turn while playing a game. His teacher also complains that he is excessively talkative, disturbs other students, and is inattentive in class.  Which of the following is the drug of choice for the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
According to the given clinical scenario, the child has ADHD. Methylphenidate is the drug of choice for the treatment of ADHD in children.

Treatment of ADHD:

  • Stimulants (first-line medications) - Methylphenidate (drug of choice), amphetamines. These drugs have a rapid onset of action and are well tolerated. The most common adverse effect is decreased appetite.
  • Non-stimulants - atomoxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), alpha-2 adrenergic agonists.
  • Behavioral therapy

As of March, 2021, the FDA has approved Azstarys, a new drug for the treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in patients 6 years of age and older. It is a CNS stimulant and consists of serdexmethylphenidate and dexmethylphenidate.

questions.text: The gastrectomy specimen of a 56-year-old woman who underwent total gastrectomy showed HER2/neu positivity. Which among the following is the drug of choice for the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Trastuzumab is the drug of choice in carcinoma stomach with HER2/neu mutation. Trastuzumab is a HER2 receptor antagonist.

Chemotherapy options in carcinoma stomach:

  • With HER2/neu mutation - Trastuzumab/Herceptin
  • With PD-L1 gene mutation - Pembrolizumab
  • Oral chemotherapy drugs:
    • Tegafur
    • Oteracil
    • Gimeracil
  • Conventional chemotherapy drugs used are 5-fluorouracil and cisplatin.

Chemotherapy is offered for patients with lymph node-positive disease and advanced gastric carcinoma (T3 and beyond) as part of palliative treatment.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning is :
questions.solution:
Dimercaprol is the drug of choice for acute arsenic poisoning.

Arsenic is an odorless, tasteless, metallic poison. Gastrointestinal features of acute arsenic poisoning include nausea and vomiting, colicky abdominal pain, and profuse diarrhea with rice water stools.

In chronic arsenic poisoning, skin symptoms include erythematous lesions, and flushing and can also lead to hyperkeratotic skin and desquamation. Pigmentation is patchy and resembles raindrops on a dusty road. In the distal parts of the body, hyperkeratosis is present.  Mees lines are transverse white striae of the fingernails, called striate leukonychia. Renal manifestations include chronic nephritis and urine contains albumin, casts, etc. 

Arsenic can be detected in the bones for prolonged periods. Hence it can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body.

Other options:

Option A: Ipecac is an emetic used in ergot and hydrocarbon poisoning.

Option B: Penicillamine is used in lead poisoning as a chelating agent. 

Option C: Activated charcoal acts as an adsorbing agent in many poisonings like aspirin, phenobarbital poisoning, etc.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient with chronic suppurative otitis media is planned for tympanoplasty. Which of the following anaesthetic agents is the best choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient undergoing tympanoplasty, which is a middle ear surgery to repair perforations in the tympanic membrane, is likely to experience post-operative nausea and vomiting (PONV). Propofol is the drug of choice for for such patients.

  • Propofol is preferred for induction in patients undergoing ear surgery
  • The inner ear is intimately involved in balance, surgeries in the ear may lead to PONV. Stimulation of the vestibular system during tympanoplasty may cause profound PONV
  • Induction and maintenance with propofol has been shown to decrease PONV in patients undergoing middle ear surgery
  • Propofol is an intravenous induction agent with antiemetic properties and so is the agent of choice in such conditions
  • The patient may also need prophylaxis with dexamethasone before induction and also a 5HT3 antagonist prior to emergence to reduce the incidence of vomiting
  • These patients should be carefully assessed for vertigo post-operatively to minimize fall risk

The patient risk factors for PONV are - 

  • Previous history of PONV
  • Female gender
  • Non-smoking status
  • Age < 50 years
  • History of chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting

Pathophysiology of PONV

Central mechanism: Stimulation of the vestibular system and environmental clues such as fear and pain may trigger the vomiting center (central pattern generator) in the medulla

Peripheral mechanism: Direct gastric stimulation from gastric trauma, blood, or toxins induces release of substance P and serotonin from enterochromaffin cells, thereby activating the vagal and splanchnic nerve 5-HT3 receptors 

Drugs and toxins: Both opioids and inhalation anesthetics may cause nausea and vomiting by stimulation of the area postrema at the base of the fourth ventricle in the medulla. The area postrema then communicates with the central pattern generator via dopamine and serotonin to trigger the vomiting reflex

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient was posted for unilateral mastectomy for breast carcinoma. Halothane was used as the inhalational agent. Intraoperatively she develops fever and tachycardia. On physical examination, rigidity was noted in the masseter muscle. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of malignant hyperthermia. The drug of choice for the condition is dantrolene.

Dantrolene is a direct-acting skeletal muscle relaxant that acts on the RyR1 (ryanodine receptor) calcium channels in the sarcoplasmic reticulum of skeletal muscles and inhibits calcium-induced calcium release. This results in the uncoupling of membrane depolarization and muscle contraction, thus inhibiting muscle contraction.

Malignant hyperthermia is a genetic condition in which mutated RyR1 receptors are present in the skeletal muscles. In the presence of certain triggers, this mutated RyR1 causes severe dysfunction in the RyR1 channels. This leads to the accumulation of calcium ions in the sarcoplasmic reticulum resulting in sustained muscle contraction, rigidity, increased heat production, acidosis, hyperkalemia, and increased end-tidal CO2.

Drugs triggering malignant hyperthermia:

  • Succinylcholine
  • Halothane
  • Isoflurane
  • Sevoflurane

Susceptible patients:

  • Patients with a positive family history. It can be inherited as an autosomal dominant trait.
  • Patients with congenital myopathies.

Treatment: 

Dantrolene sodium is the drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia. Once the diagnosis is made, the causative inhalational agent should be stopped immediately. Supportive treatment with rapid cooling, inhalation of 100% oxygen, control of acidosis, and treatment of hyperkalemia should be given

Other options:

Options A and C: Succinylcholine and isoflurane are known to cause malignant hyperthermia, and hence cannot be used for the management.

Option D: Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing skeletal muscle relaxant.

questions.text: A sample of peripheral blood was collected during the night at 1 am for a patient admitted with bilateral lower limb non-pitting edema and the smear microscopy showed the presence of an organism as given in the image below. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
The image demonstrates sheathed microfilaria with nuclei-free tail tip indicative of Wuchereria bancrofti. The clinical scenario is suggestive of elephantiasis. The drug of choice is Diethylcarbamazine (DEC)

DEC is used in the treatment of lymphatic filariasis and loasis at a daily dosage of 4-6 mg/kg for 14 days. 

The disease can present as classical filariasis or occult filariasis. Clinical features include:

Classical filariasis- Fever, lymphangitis, hydrocele, elephantiasis(non-pitting brawny edema), milky white urine(chylous), etc.

Occult filariasis- Massive eosinophilia, hepatosplenomegaly, dyspnea, arthritis, glomerulonephritis, etc. 

Diagnosis is confirmed by the demonstration of microfilaria in blood, chylous urine, exudate of lymph varix, and hydrocele fluid.  The filarial species is nocturnally periodic,  hence it is preferable to collect night blood samples between 10 pm and 4 am. Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice.

Image showing elephantiasis:

Other options: 

Option B: Ivermectin is the preferred drug for the treatment of  Strongyloides stercoralis infection. Ivermectin given orally for 2 days is considered the treatment of choice for human strongyloidiasis. Extended treatment for at least 14 days or at least a week after parasites have been eradicated is required in case of disseminated strongyloidiasis.

Option C: Praziquantel is the drug of choice for the treatment of infections caused by trematodes like Schistosoma, Clonorchis, Opisthorchis, Fasciolopis, Paragonimus, and cestodes like Hymenolepis, Diphyllobothrium, and Taenia.

Option D: Albendazole is the drug of choice for infections caused by nematodes like Ascaris and Trichura, and in cases of neurocysticercosis caused by larval forms of Taenia solium, a cestode.

questions.text: A post-op patient develops purulent discharge from the incision site. The culture report shows Staphylococcus aureus resistant to an antibiotic that binds to the terminal  D ala-D ala sequence. Which of the following antibiotics is the drug of choice to treat this infection?
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests vancomycin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (VRSA) and daptomycin is the drug of choice for this condition.

Daptomycin acts by first binding to the cytoplasmic membrane and then forming complexes in a calcium-dependent manner. Complex formation causes a rapid loss of cellular potassium, possibly by pore formation, and membrane depolarization. This is followed by the arrest of DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis resulting in cell death.    

The given scenario is that of a skin infection secondary to VRSA. Vancomycin is the antibiotic that binds to the terminal D ala-D ala sequence of peptidoglycan units needed for bacterial cell wall synthesis.

Other options:

Option A: Ceftazidime is a third-generation cephalosporin that is ineffective in VRSA infections.

Option B: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside which is ineffective in VRSA infections

Option C: As the culture reports already show resistance to vancomycin, this is not the answer. However, vancomycin is the drug of choice for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).

questions.text: A patient who has been treated for shingles over his right trigeminal region 3 months ago now complains of recurrent burning sensation over the same region. Which of the following is the drug of choice ?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with previous history of shingles and recurrent burning sensation over the same region for the past 3 months is suggestive of post-herpetic neuralgia and neurotrophic agents like amitriptyline are the drug of choice.

Recurrence of the varicella zoster infection is called shingles and the presentation here shows herpes zoster ophthalmicus, since it relapses in the trigeminal nerve. Drugs like acyclovir and prednisolone are best effective during the acute phase of the infection and not for post-herpetic neuralgia.

In extreme cases, drugs like carbamazepine can also be used to treat this condition.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for managing Ogilvie's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Neostigmine is the drug of choice for the management of Ogilvie's syndrome. 

Ogilvie's syndrome, also known as acute colonic pseudo-obstruction is characterized by massive colonic dilation in the absence of mechanical obstruction. Pharmacological management aims to enhance colonic motility and reduce the risk of colonic perforation.

Neostigmine, a cholinesterase inhibitor, is the drug of choice for Ogilvie's syndrome as it increases acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction, leading to enhanced colonic smooth muscle contraction and relief of colonic distention. Pharmacologic management with Neostigmine is indicated only if there is no clinical improvement after 48 hours of conservative management.

Initial conservative management is the first line in managing stable patients or mildly symptomatic patients with cecal dilation <12 cm and includes monitoring with serial X-rays or USG and stomach decompression with an NG tube.

Other options: 

Option A: Loperamide is an antidiarrheal agent and is not indicated for the management of Ogilvie's syndrome. Its mechanism of action involves slowing gastrointestinal motility and increasing colonic transit time.

Option B: Bisacodyl is a stimulant laxative that acts by increasing intestinal motility and promoting bowel movements. While it may be used in the management of constipation, it is not recommended for Ogilvie's syndrome due to the risk of exacerbating colonic distention.

Option D: Ondansetron is a serotonin receptor antagonist primarily used for the management of nausea and vomiting. It does not directly affect colonic motility and is not indicated for the treatment of Ogilvie's syndrome.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy with a known diagnosis of sickle cell disease presents with fever and painful swelling of hands and feet. Which of the following is the drug of choice to prevent painful crises in sickle cell anaemia?
questions.solution:
Hydroxyurea is the drug of choice for the prevention of painful crises in sickle cell anaemia.

Hydroxyurea is a myelosuppressive agent that is effective in reducing the frequency of painful episodes, decreasing the rate of hospitalization and requirement for blood transfusion. It is safe and well-tolerated in children and infants.

Other options:

  • Hydrocodone is used in the treatment of pain crisis in sickle cell anaemia.
  • Corticosteroids is one of the first-line therapies for acute idiopathic thrombocytic purpura (ITP) with risk factors for bleeding.
  • Ruxolitinib is the drug of choice for treatment of polycythemia vera.
